ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: - a course that offers a broad and inclusive sweep of western models for approaching art history; beneficial for those especially studying western art history - I would recommend for its provision of tools and theoretical frameworks for study of art
It's required for PhD students in the discipline, so you need to take it.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Yes, my background is not in European painting and it was very helpful to gain a greater familiarity with the methods pertaining therein. Beyond this, I do think that even in the work that I do outside of that area I was pushed to think more critically about what it means to study the history of art and have begun reflecting on my own work in a new way. I still feel I have a lot of "methods" work to do in my own discipline and would have appreciated if the course had covered some of that terrain, but I think my discipline in particular can benefit from some of the critical approaches we covered in class so I appreciate the opportunity to become more familiar with them.
I mostly focus on visual culture, and thankfully there were weeks that surprisingly and delightfully addressed this!
This course offered a strong overview of major methodologies in the history of art and helped me sharpen my understanding of my interests and approaches.
